page.title: 04KILDRUMMIE KAMES GOLLANFIELD
page.content: The{Kildrummie Kames }are large mounds of sand and gravel,left by the melting glaciers.The{Kames}go from east to west;some of the{kames}reach fifty feet in places.They are separated by arable and boggy ground.The farmers are not allowad to plough on them,but they are allowed to use them for grazing pasture.The ridges are noticeable because the ground is flat. In between the kames there are two very important lochs. There is Loch Flemington and the Loch of the Clans.At Loch Flemington lots of birds breed and they also breed at Loch of the Clans. The birds that breed at the Lochs are mute swans, mallards,tufted ducks,moorhens , coots and grebes.It is an area of Special Scientific Interest.
